snippet.textDisplay: First game where when the intro ends you still think you're watching a cinematic then after a minute you're like "Wait, I'm in-game now ??"

snippet.textDisplay:
A city where the artist would not fear the censor.
Where the scientist would not be bound by petty morality.
Where the great would not be constrained by the small!
snippet.textOriginal:
A city where the artist would not fear the censor.
Where the scientist would not be bound by petty morality.
Where the great would not be constrained by the small!

snippet.textDisplay:
I am Andrew Ryan, and I'm here to ask you a question.
Is a man not entitled to the sweat of his brow?
'No!' says the man in Washington, 'It belongs to the poor.'
'No!' says the man in the Vatican, 'It belongs to God.'
'No!' says the man in Moscow, 'It belongs to everyone.'
I rejected those answers. I chose something different.
I chose the impossible. I chose...Rapture.
snippet.textOriginal:
I am Andrew Ryan, and I'm here to ask you a question.
Is a man not entitled to the sweat of his brow?
'No!' says the man in Washington, 'It belongs to the poor.'
'No!' says the man in the Vatican, 'It belongs to God.'
'No!' says the man in Moscow, 'It belongs to everyone.'
I rejected those answers. I chose something different.
I chose the impossible. I chose...Rapture.

snippet.textDisplay:
They tried to change it in BSI by giving you only 2 weapons at a time, which adds realism, but I'm not a fan of.
Still, if they removed plasmids (or vigors, whatever), people would rage a lot. I prefer they take a safer route with the combat mechanic (and adapt the surrounding world instead), than mess the entire gameplay structure for the sake of novelty.
But I get what you mean, it would be fun to expand a bit the gameplay. I'm sure Levine and his team would do a great job. :-)
snippet.textOriginal:
They tried to change it in BSI by giving you only 2 weapons at a time, which adds realism, but I'm not a fan of.
Still, if they removed plasmids (or vigors, whatever), people would rage a lot. I prefer they take a safer route with the combat mechanic (and adapt the surrounding world instead), than mess the entire gameplay structure for the sake of novelty.
But I get what you mean, it would be fun to expand a bit the gameplay. I'm sure Levine and his team would do a great job. :-)

snippet.textDisplay: Oh absolutely, it's tha fact that it hasn't really changed or evolved over all three games that I find dissapointing. That doesn't mean it isn't 1000x better than your average mms :P
snippet.textOriginal: Oh absolutely, it's tha fact that it hasn't really changed or evolved over all three games that I find dissapointing. That doesn't mean it isn't 1000x better than your average mms :P

snippet.textDisplay:
It's still infinitely (pun!) better than modern war shooters, which give you about 12 different machine guns and they ALL shoot the same.
The various combinations of weapons + plasmids (8*8) gives so much more depths to the gameplay than most of other shooters out there. I'm astoundished that you found the gameplay clumsy or boring.
Having more than 5 ways to approach an enemy is so much funnier than simply charging and shooting.
The only bad point IMO is the lack of difficulty...
snippet.textOriginal:
It's still infinitely (pun!) better than modern war shooters, which give you about 12 different machine guns and they ALL shoot the same.

The only bad point IMO is the lack of difficulty...

snippet.textDisplay: The plane crash is one of my fav cinematic videogame scenes. So good. I wasn't sure if it was FMV at first.
snippet.textOriginal: The plane crash is one of my fav cinematic videogame scenes. So good. I wasn't sure if it was FMV at first.

snippet.textDisplay: Thats THE bad point of the series for sure, the actual combat gameplay hasn't really changed through the entire series. The music, stories and design are definantly the main draws :)
snippet.textOriginal: Thats THE bad point of the series for sure, the actual combat gameplay hasn't really changed through the entire series. The music, stories and design are definantly the main draws :)

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm one of those odd people who've never played through either Bioshock 1 or 2 (although number 2 was given to me by a friend). I've certainly tried, but found the gameplay being "clumsy", in lack of a better word.
I managed to plough through Infinite. I found the story to be great, but other than that... meh :S
But I've always admired the music in these games!
snippet.textOriginal:

I managed to plough through Infinite. I found the story to be great, but other than that... meh :S
But I've always admired the music in these games!

snippet.textDisplay: Weird, I've played 2 and Infinite, but never this one. I know the story(internet spoils everything)but I have yet to experience it myself, and have done a good job of forgetting a number of the crucial details. How's it hold compared to the others?

snippet.textDisplay: Also, this game still holds my spot for the best introduction to a game.  From the plane crash to the ride into Rapture, panning over the destruction and the voice over from Ryan, it puts you in the mood you need to be in to fully appreciate the game and makes you feel like you are in that world, helpless and afraid of the unknown in front of you.
snippet.textOriginal: Also, this game still holds my spot for the best introduction to a game.  From the plane crash to the ride into Rapture, panning over the destruction and the voice over from Ryan, it puts you in the mood you need to be in to fully appreciate the game and makes you feel like you are in that world, helpless and afraid of the unknown in front of you.

snippet.textDisplay: God, this song brings back so many memories.  While I liked the story in Infinite, I thought the gameplay was pretty bad compared to this one and I wish they hadn't cut so much.
snippet.textOriginal: God, this song brings back so many memories.  While I liked the story in Infinite, I thought the gameplay was pretty bad compared to this one and I wish they hadn't cut so much.

Also I love this song, shame it's so short.

snippet.textDisplay: Mixed with the amazingly appropriate 1930s music, you can feel how life must have been on Rapture before the tragic events. Bioshock 2 was also very good, but the novelty aspect was mostly gone, while I found Bioshock Infinite great but lacking in terms of complex level design.
snippet.textOriginal: Mixed with the amazingly appropriate 1930s music, you can feel how life must have been on Rapture before the tragic events. Bioshock 2 was also very good, but the novelty aspect was mostly gone, while I found Bioshock Infinite great but lacking in terms of complex level design.

snippet.textDisplay: Rapture is my favorite fictional setting in a video game ever. The intro where you're diving down to discover the underwater city for the first time while this music plays is something I'll always remember. I bought my 360 with this game too, so I was also in awe of the graphics (which, 6 years later, still look awesome). Not just the graphics on a technical level, but also (and mainly) on an artistic level.
snippet.textOriginal: Rapture is my favorite fictional setting in a video game ever. The intro where you're diving down to discover the underwater city for the first time while this music plays is something I'll always remember. I bought my 360 with this game too, so I was also in awe of the graphics (which, 6 years later, still look awesome). Not just the graphics on a technical level, but also (and mainly) on an artistic level.
